header.title: Hollywood's Sexism: Salma Hayek & Matthias Schoenaerts - Women In Motion
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Salma Hayek & Matthias Schoenaerts discuss discrimination against women in Hollywood at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival during their Women in Motion talk Presented by Kering. Subscribe to our channel: https://www.youtube.com/hollywoodrepo... Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/HollywoodRep... Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/thr. Follow us on Instagram: http://instagram.com/hollywoodreporter. Watch more videos on THR.com http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/video
header.socioLingVar: Gender - General,Physical Identity - Physical (and Mental) Impairments,Age - Over 65s,Age - Youngsters

commentThread.commentText: You can have a box in your brain and not need to be a man or a woman. I believe we are unique and we must give ourselves value so we can live better and others will see it and they will appreciate us. It is important to remember where we come from and come back to nature and 'old style' if we feel lost. Teamwork is the key to me. We don't need to create a war to see who's better if men or women. We have high intuition as a female and they get better oriented. There are many activities that should be done by each one. Our bodies are designed differently. It's like being ring and shoe size 7 and trying to fit 6 or 8. As a woman we can go to school, work outside the house, pay our bills, maintain our kids, everything alone and because of that men are not gentlemen anymore. I don't understand how looking for freedom we just lost commitment and kindness. I'm a woman, independent, bilingual, with some college and I just would do anything to be treated with respect and kindness as old women from the past were treated. Women that without going to school, with no liberty, with no knowledge about home activities, I mean doing homework themselves, they got a position in society and lived their lives as it supposed to be at that time. It's so sad to see our future. Maybe we won't speak in future, just push keys on a screen to get what we want. It's depressing. I hope things change and even though money it's very important and keeps order there's still value out there. Nature doesn't cost a cent. It exists to be appreciated, to be lived, and to make us understand the real meaning of life.

Hayek can't even speak English without an accent - that's why she can't get good American roles. She needs to stop complaining and get a voice coach. Even the Belgian guy has less of an accent than her.

commentThread.commentText: 'I don't believe I have a right to complain about anything, unless I make an effort to make a difference.' -Salma Hayek

I can very much relate to what Matthias said about becoming cynical because of the "ower-awareness" (34:08). It makes me cynical, sad and angry too. But is there an over-awareness? We are still nowhere near equality. And what shall we (women) do? It affects our lives so much, we face it practically every day! "She's not cut out to do this and that, she is too gentle", "Such a career! She must be a bitch" etc.


I wrote my master thesis in linguistics about the perceived power in male and female speech of characters in a Star Wars animated series. Although all my characters had high positions of power in the Star Wars universe, the perceived power (of us human watchers) was very different. Still a long way to go to reach eye-level.

replies.commentText: ' ... that the curtain has been drawn for him ... ' Sorry, what? I totally do not understand what you are trying to express ... I'm from BE, I totally share Matthias's views. I prefer a strong woman - or better said - a vulnerable woman who is real but strong (because - in my view - this is reality) over any testosterone induced superhero. OK, getting that off my chest, I totally love Salma for her beauty (hey, I'm a man) but mostly/if not entirely for her smartness.

at around 33:14 - after Salma points out the power role of the male leads in the inequality of the movie industry. The reporter asks him what/will he do anything differently from this point on and his response is that he isn't going to change/aggressively pursue anything. "I don't want to be over aware about these kinda things - it makes me cynical . . . I want to stay away from it . . . focus on the good things . . . not from a polarized perspective." -- so he's not going to stand for anything.

MyDesertLove dotCom I didn't get that at all from what he said. He didn't say he wasn't going to stand up for anything, he simply said he will continue to judge people as individuals and look at the situation rather than on group identification society so often uses today. I'm not sure what you expect him to do. Just because he's male does not make him inherently sexist nor does it make it his job to fix sexism within the industry. If he encountered sexism of course hopefully he would speak out but the idea that he needs to take a step back from his own career for women is wrong in my opinion. He does not represent all men and should be judged not by hi s gender but by his actions and words.

Agree with all those super impressed with Salma. She had great points and she expressed them passionately. Matthias seemed to have thought a lot less about these issues. His comments around 19:00 about seeing the human being before identities such as black/white/Asian/Latino or male/female, etc. is tone-deaf. Criticizing identity politics is something people in positions of privilege often do. It's easy to be white and male and say "I just see people, not race, gender etc." Try living wit h racis m, sexism, transphobia etc on a daily basis. You don't get a choice about "just being human". Many people put you in a box; THAT is your reality. As a minority you have to navigate those waters. For minorities, identity politics is the path to pursue justice and equality. In short, minorities don't have the privilege to ignore identity politics. Matthias should question his own privilege and the space he is afforded that others are not to "see people as humans first." Just my humble opinion, though I think he means well.

Whoops!  I made a technical error.  This previous post that notes Burke Carey as the writer is from his mother, Penny Carey, not Burke.

I saw Far From the Maddening Crowds and was so impressed.  I also applaud Schoenaerts comments about sexism which is rampant everywhere but I wonder if he is the best candidate for this panel. You see, I also saw Schoenaerts interview for NY Magazine where he states that Mike Tyson was his "childhood hero".  Mike Tyson, a convicted rapist and alleged wife abuser.  I ask myself what can be more sexist than rape and abuse and why glorify a man who has been convicted of it?  Never mind the poor sportsmanship of biting off Hollyfield's ear.  Watching Schoenaerts for me was like watching a person speaking from both sides of his mouth.  I am not on a crusade against Mike Tyson personally.  There are too many sexual predators out there to be limited to one.  My heros are the women and men (although there are far fewer of them) who against incredible pressure stand up to their abusers to speak out and the people who stand with them.  I know I will probably receive a lot of criticism for this post; probably called a fem-Nazi and other such terms that will not bother me.  Actually though, I am a 60 yea r ol >d woman who has been married for 30 years with a wonderful son.  There are a lot of men in my life who I love and have loved.  My 17 y ear old son boxes too but would never hold Mike Tyson up as a hero.  He knows that the sexual abuse I experienced a t the age of 7 from the hands of a deacon of the Baptist Church has affected my  whole life.  This predator later went on the sexually ab use an old women and two more girls  (that I know of) and never brought to justice.  One of the greatest regrets of my life was that I was too traumatized and young at the time to speak out.  I speak out now and ask that Schoenaerts grow up from his "childhood heros" and not tout convicted rapists as heroes.  It is offensive and, besides, there are many truer heros of boxing... Muhammed Ali, Jack Demspy, and Roy Hamilton (a Golden Gloves boxer who a artist with a voice that rivaled Sinatra).

replies.commentText: No way he said that! Do you have a link? I love Matty it can't be

I agree with what you're saying regarding how a rapist and wife-beater like Tyson should never be considered a hero, but I can't help but wonder in what context Matthias mentioned him as his childhood hero. In Belgium Tyson was the only boxer we - Matthias' generation - were exposed to. Remember there was no internet so we had what the weekly magazines were offering us, and Tyson and his beautiful wife Robin Givens were darlings of the Belgian press (this changed after the accusations of spousal abuse and rape). I don't like boxing, and I consider myself a feminist, but growing up in Belgium in the 1980s and early 90s Mike Tyson was (what I conceived then as) one of the most glamorous and almost superhuman stars I was exposed to, and I would read about him whenever I had a chance. So when you ask me about people who made an impression on me as a kid I might mention him, as he was how my childhood self imagined America to be: larger than life. This is of course very separate from how I view Tyson now (and I'm shocked to read there will be a film about his life). Just wondering if this could be what Matthias meant...

I think about Matthias as a very sensitive person, at least this was the message that all his interview gaves to me, and all the movie roles he tooks. I saw that interview too, and I can say that at the beginning I remained pretty disappointed when I heard him mentioning Tyson, BUT we should think about it in a more intelligent perspective. We should see Matthias throught his real choices, when he was mature, then when he was a young little boy. Tyson was a role model for a lot of young kids as a BOXER for sure not for his life choices. For concluding I simply think that the choice that he made when he was a kid, doesn't affect who he is as a man, and doesn'gt affect the fact that he always showed up as a very sensible human being with a big curiosity for human types. Don't accuse him of someone he is not, don-t confuse him with someone he looked up when he was a little kid. Judge him based on what he says and which are his real opinion who he spoke about openly.

replies.commentText: I am Mexican and I also find her accent a little too heavy, (I wonder if my accent is also like that haha,) but as she has been living in the states for long, she could have improved it. Perhaps she does in purpose as she seems more proud of being Hispanic in this moment of her life. And your "neighbour" Matthias, he is absolutely cute, I have watched three of his films in one week (:

+Corry Helmond is harder to get rid of an accent when you are a grown up, she lived in the the U.S when she started her career in Hollywood but she hasn't lived there for many years now, she lives in France. I remember watching some of her interviews when she was younger and her accent wasn't as thick as it is now.

+Corry Helmond I think its incredibly unfair to bet annoyed of an accent. THis feeling is simply stemming from the fact that most likely you are not used to that accent at all and so are uncomfortable with it, while the same is untrue of American accents. As an Indian, I find American accents incredibly annoying simply because I'm not used to them. That does not mean its fair to say that they must have my accent in my country or I must get their accent in their country. USA accents are seen as less annoying only because of the fact that Hollywood is huge all over the world, and people can get used to American accents by watching films. But nobody except one of that sam e nationality watch films of their own country. I don't think there's anything known as a normal accent. Suggesting that people better get used to talking "American" in America only creates one bland accent for all instead of the great cultural tapestry of various accents. Diversity is best promoted by identifying these accents and keeping them. They are a part of that country's culture. Kudos to Salma for holding onto her accent. If she wants to keep it, its fine. If people want to change their accent, that's cool too. Just don't suggest that all must try to have one accent.

Pran97, Magnifique! 
You said it brilliantly. Very well done!!!.......... There's also the fact that Salma, speaks three or four languages, by now.
You think that's a heavy accent?? Honey...
Corry Helmond as Mexican I can assure you,our accent is our beauty and even if we try we will never get rid of it

commentThread.commentText: Just be honest.  Hollywood is the way it is because it's run by a small group.  It's not just male. It's white males.  And it's not just white males, it's Jewish white males.  When you are dealing with such a small sliver of the population you're going to rfind homogeneity.   And THAT is truly why Hollywood makes the films it does, because they see the world through their own prism of invariability, and they project that invariability onto audiences everywhere.  It's not that they are evil.  Those in Hollywood just aren't sophisticated thinkers.  They think they are breaking the mold with black jokes and Al Jolsen-esque style of perpetuating stereotypes in order to elevate their own culture closer to the traditional ideal.  Salma is correct in pointing out that we are smarter than that and we aren't buying it, literally.

commentThread.commentText: Dear Salma Hayek, I listened to all of your remarks and your observations are surely true and relevant but let's remember the many actresses who made a name on their own no matter how briljant their male counterparts were, they are remembered and not just as a sex-symbol. I'll start the list in the '50: Anna Magnani, Sophia Loren, Gina Lolobridgida,Claudia Cardinale, Giulietta Massini ...( the Italian ones)...Simonne Signoret, Jeanne Moreau, Brigitte Bardot, Danielle Darieux, Catherine Deneuve, Juliette Binoche ...(French)...Romy Schneider...and many others that NO male actor ever had any problem to act with. If I would list the American or British actresses the list would be very large. I think that a lot of male actors - in an eventual leading role or even second role- just always like to work with actresses that meet-up with their notion of what their role in a film asks for. It is not about who they want to kiss or not. If the talent is there they'll jump. Of course I am aware that a lot of talent remains underestimated...that is the same traject for male and female actresses. A real Light can never be kept under the carpet. The female directors are only a few, I agree. But women are not inclined as much as men to go all the way through the difficulties that every moviemaker encounters when presenting their project to (eventual) producers. There are women willing to go all the way. You are one of them. There are briljant female script writers...but are you aware of the amount of briljant male writers who are dismissed just the same way? Male directors that are sent home just the same way female directors are sent home? And yes Matthias Schoenaerts, as a person with common sense and sensitivity, is not making a difference between men or women when reading a script, not making any difference between men and women when the director is pointed out, not making any question about who is gonna be his female costar, because IT IS ALL ABOUT: WHAT IS THE STORY WE wanna tell, HOW WE GONNA tell that story, WILL WE BE ABLE to tell that story HOW IT NEEDS TO BE TOLD.

replies.commentText: @Silent Mama I completely agree with you, not as many women are interested in the rigorous work that is FILMMAKING, just as there are less than 5% of women working as garbage collectors. Different professions attract different people, and men face the same problems that women face when trying to become a filmmaker. While there is some discrimination against women in film, it doesn't mean that we should forcefully give women more jobs in filmmaking just for the sake of diversity, because that wouldn't be fair to the countless more men who may be more qualified for the job. I think the job of director, producer, writer, etc. should go to the person who can do the job the best, regardless of whether it's a woman or a man. Since more men are interested in fimmaking in general, it makes sense that in turn, more men are working as filmmakers. The low number of women may in part be because of sexism, but I don't think it's as big of a setback as people claim it to be; there are simply less women interested in the profession.

I agree with both of you, we should stop talking about numbers and genders, we should go over it as Matthias does, sensivity is the key, give the job to the people are the best in doing it, and don-t care if they are more man then women or the opposite. The success will come when we will look at each other recognizing our talents and in what we are the best, not the gender. Really embrace diversity, and not because it's a trend.
